[MR SPEAKER IN THE CHAIR] ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION ACT (Payment of damages)

1. Mr L. P. Rodrigo asked the Minister for Labour if he will consider introducing legislation to amend section 41 of the Workmen's Compensation Act or any other appropriate sections thereof or other legislation to provide that, in cases where the injured workman has instituted legal proceedings to recover damages or compensation independently of the Act, payment of such damages as are awarded by the Court or compensation secured which exceed $500 shall be made to the Public Trustee as trustee for the person entitled to the benefit.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by my Minister to reply.

Section 41 of the Workmen's Compensation Act, besides giving an injured workman the choice of either claiming compensation under the Act or instituting action for damages in common law,

also at the same time reserves his right to revert to the Workmen's Compensation Act should he fail in common law. Any payment of compensation under the Act is made by the Commissioner directly to the claimants and, unless he directs otherwise, no insurer or employer may pay directly to the claimant. The Commissioner, however, cannot withhold any sum due to a claimant except minors in respect of whom he holds the amounts due in trust until they reach the age of 18.

It is agreed that neither under the present Workmen's Compensation Act nor in common law are safeguards provided to prevent a claimant from being exploited by unscrupulous persons or from squandering away the lump sum awarded to him. However, the present Act is being completely revamped. The new Bill not only provides for increased quantum of compensation but would also empower the Commissioner for Labour to withhold such sum in the interests of the claimant. He can, under the new Bill, make monthly payments instead of one lump sum, thereby ensuring that the claimant is assured of a steady monthly income.

I do not think that section 41, as explained above, is the most appropriate section to amend in order to make provision that if any payment of compensation exceeding $500 is made to a workman by his employer in common law, then it should be made to the Public Trustee.

Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Parliamentary Secretary in a position to inform this House when this new Bill will be introduced?

Mr Fong Sip Chee: Sir, this Bill is in an advanced stage of drafting, and as soon as it is ready it will be tabled in this House for the consideration of Members.

ANSON COMMUNITY CENTRE (Alternative site)

2. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Culture if the Anson Community Centre is affected by urban redevelopment and where the alternative site for the Centre will be.

The Minister for Culture (Mr Jek Yeun Thong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is yes, the Anson Community Centre will be affected by urban redevelopment. However, the plan has not yet been finalised and the Urban Redevelopment Authority is not able to tell when the community centre will be affected and where the alternative site will be. The Member for Anson will be informed when the site is known, and his views will be sought when the time comes.

SUPREME COURT (Public address system)

3. Mr L. P. Rodrigo asked the Minister for Law and National Development if the Government will consider the installation of public address systems in the courtrooms of the Supreme Court to ensure that justice is not only seen but also heard.

The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Sir, the Government does not consider that there is a need to provide for the installation of public address systems in the air-conditioned courtrooms in the Supreme Court.

Mr L. P. Rodrigo (Serangoon Gardens): Sir, with one experience behind us, can the Minister inform the House whether or not the Subordinate Court buildings that are nearing completion will be installed with sufficient public address systems to ensure that justice there will be heard?

Mr Barker: There will be a public address system in the Senior Magistrates' Courts in the new Subordinate Courts building to enable parties appearing thereto to hear their summonses being called. This Court will be the Court where the majority of criminal cases are first mentioned.

REORGANISATION OF PRISONS DEPARTMENT (Progress made)

4. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Health and Home Affairs (a) what progress has been made in the reorganisation of the Prisons Department since early 1973; (b) if his Ministry proposes to recommend revision of salaries of Prisons Officers; and (c) what steps have been taken to give Prisons Officers the four off-days per month.

The Minister for Health and Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government appointed a Committee to study the reorganisation of the Prisons Department in February 1973. The Committee made a comprehensive review of the Prisons Department and studied, inter alia, the sentences imposed on criminals, the systems of rehabilitation of prisoners and the pay and service conditions of the staff of the Prisons Department. The final Report was submitted to the Ministry of Home Affairs in March 1974.

The Committee made various recommendations, including a salary revision for the Prisons staff. The Government has since accepted in principle the recommendations (other than those relating to the salary scales) and directed that the reorganisation of the Prisons Department as recommended should be proceeded with.

Agreement has also been reached with the Finance Ministry to revise the salary scales of the custodial ranks in the Prisons Service and these have been implemented with effect from 1st August, 1974.

Because of the peculiar nature of prison work, it is not possible to give Prison officers regularly four off-days per month. They are given one off-day in a fortnight and, they do not, on the aggregate, work more than 44 hours per week.

Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, the Prisons Department's recommendations have been accepted by the Government. Is it true that the salary scales for senior officers have also been accepted?

Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have already answered that question just now. As I said, all the recommendations of the Committee have been accepted, except those relating to salaries. As far as salaries are concerned, an agreement has been reached between the Finance Ministry and the Home Affairs Ministry with regard to the revision of salaries, particularly those of the custodial staff, and that the improvement in the salaries of the custodial staff

has been implemented on 1st August this year.

Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, has the Home Affairs Ministry recommended to the Ministry of Finance its support for the implementation of these salary scales?

Mr Chua Sian Chin: I have said that as far as the custodial staff are concerned, recommendations for a salary revision had been put to the Finance Ministry, and they have agreed to it.

Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, are the senior officers included in the salary revision scheme?

Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, the salary revision is for all the Prisons staff. But, as I have said, the improvements of salaries have been effected for the custodial staff.

VIGILANTE CORPS (Particulars)

5. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Health and Home Affairs (a) if he will give facts and figures of the progress and work of the Vigilante Corps; (b) what is the ratio of members of the Corps to instructors; (c) what measures have been taken to counsel members of the Corps who are frequently absent from parades; and (d) if he is aware that due to the poor quality of uniforms supplied to members of the Corps many of them prefer to stitch their own uniform, and what steps are being taken in this matter.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Lim Guan Hoo) (for the Minister for Health and Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by my Minister to reply.

The Vigilante Corps (VC) was reorganised into a National Service organisation for part-time National Servicemen in 1967. Since then it has a constant inflow of about 5,000 National Servicemen annually. With the intake of more

members, the Corps was able to extend its service in 1971 to include Civil Defence training for its part-time National Servicemen. Early this year its service was further extended with the establishment of the Community Security Force (CSF).

Today, the Vigilante Corps has emerged as a large and expanding disciplined force. Out of a total of 31,089 National Servicemen in the Corps as at 30th September, 1974: -

(i) 11,208 are in the Vigilante Service;

(ii) 13,318 are in the Civil Defence Service;

(iii) 5,892 are in the Community Security Service; and

(iv) 671 are in the Auxiliary Fire Service.

The Vigilante Service is a mass youth organisation which seeks to inculcate in the men a sense of social consciousness, responsibility and discipline through civics and organised youth activities. Specific cultural groups have been formed to enrich the cultural life of our young citizens. In addition, a Lifeguard Unit was set up in February this year. Within a brief span of eight months since its inception, members of the Lifeguard Unit have saved the lives of 13 persons.

In the Civil Defence Service, the National Servicemen are trained in rescue operations, first-aid and fire-fighting, so as to meet any national emergency. Included in this field of service recently is the introduction of Lift Rescue Training. It is hoped that the availability of a group of well-trained VC National Servicemen for such rescue work will help to minimise the inconvenience that can be caused to HDB flat-dwellers in the event of power failure.

Since the Community Security Force became operational in January this year, there has been a significant reduction in crime between 7 p.m, and 11 p.m, in the crime-prone areas selected for CSF

policing service. During the first six months of this year, there were on the average 21 days per month during which such areas were free of crime because of the presence of the CSF members.

The ratio of instructors to members of the Corps is 1 : 125. However, as there are some vacancies in the instructorate, the actual ratio is 1 : 172. Steps are being taken to fill the vacancies.

The Vigilante Corps has set up a counselling service for VC National Servicemen. It is part of the job of this counselling unit to go into individual cases of those who are habitually absent from duty or training. They also visit homes of habitual absentees to find out their problems and advise them to return for training or duty. Absentees working in shifts or at night are allowed to do their training during the day. Alternatively, they can attend make-up training subsequently, provided they are granted leave of absence from the usual training in advance. It should, however, be pointed out that the counselling service is not the decisive factor in reducing the absentee rate in the Vigilante Corps. With suitable punitive measures and an improved training programme, the Corps has now been able to cut down drastically the rate of absenteeism. As at 1st April, 1974, there were a total of 2,494 bad absentees and gazetted deserters in the Vigilante Corps. This number was reduced to 909 as at 30th September this year. Taking into account that the total strength of the Vigilante Corps today is 30,984 (excluding 105 deserters), the overall absentee rate has now dropped to an all-time low of 2.9 per cent.

In a mass uniformed organisation like the Vigilante Corps, it is not possible for all members of the Corps to be provided with made-to-measure uniforms. However, every effort has been made to improve upon the style and comfort of the uniforms provided for members of the Corps. Prior to 1967, the national servicemen in the Vigilante Corps were provided with uniforms made of drill. This has since been changed to cotton for the shirts and teteron for the trousers.

Junior officers in the Corps are issued with uniforms made to standard sizes owing to the large numbers involved. Slight alterations to the uniforms may have to be made by individuals. The senior officers are provided with made-to-measure uniforms in view of their smaller numbers.

DRUGS REGISTRATION BOARD (Setting up of)

6. Dr Tan Eng Liang asked the Minister for Health and Home Affairs whether he is considering the setting up of a board for the registration of drugs, and what measures are contemplated to ensure that drugs are of clinical and therapeutic efficacy and are proven safe from dangerous side-effects.

The Minister of State for Health (Dr Ang Kok Peng) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, the setting up of a board for the registration of drugs is being considered as one of the ways in which the proposed Medicines Act may be administered. It will be necessary to draw on the experience in drug control and safety of other countries, such as the United Kingdom which has a similar Medicines Act. For instance, in U.K. there are several committees which undertake various and different aspects of drug control. There is a Medicines Committee which is charged with advising on the general policies concerning medicines, answering questions put to it, and volunteering information. There are also other expert committees such as that on Safety of Medicines, and the Pharmacopoeia Commission, as well as sub-committees such as on the prevention of microbial contamination of medicines. In our case, where necessary, committees along similar lines may be formed in due course.

The basic measure to ensure safety, efficacy and the quality of medicine will be by licensing. Licensing of the products (in other words, a registration of

the products) will be based on evidence of the following: -

(a) The product does not contain any deleterious substance;

(b) There is good quality control in manufacture;

(c) There has been exhaustive and comprehensive testing chemically, by bio-assays and by clinical trials; and

(d) They are marketed in approved forms.

As a corollary it will have to eliminate drugs which are of doubtful safety, efficacy and quality. Drugs will be screened on the basis of scientific evidence of safety, efficacy and compliance with the principles of internationally accepted standards of good manufacturing practice.

The Ministry has now five officers with overseas training in quality control of drugs and in procedures of drug registration. Inspectors will be appointed to see that the conditions imposed are observed by product licencees. They will visit the premises of manufacturers applying for licences and also do spot checks on licence holders. Drug wholesalers will have to maintain a specified standard of record-keeping and storage facilities. It will be an offence to make false or misleading statements in an advertisement.

Dr Tan Eng Liang (River Valley): Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Ministry of Health, in considering the setting up of a board for the registration of drugs, provide facilities for screening? What I mean is besides just checking on the claims of an importer of a particular new drug, will the Ministry of Health itself have the facilities to test the claims?

Dr Ang Kok Peng: We have not yet quite decided on the establishment of a board. At this stage of drafting the Bill, I am in no position to specify the details on how we would implement this measure of drug control.

MEDICINES BILL (Introduction of)

7. Dr Tan Eng Liang asked the Minister for Health and Home Affairs if the views of experts outside his Ministry and of interested organisations and associations are being sought in the drafting of the Medicines Bill, and when the Bill will be introduced.

The Minister of State for Health (Dr Ang Kok Peng) (for the Minister for Health and Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not the usual practice to seek the views of interested organisations and associations at the stage when a law is being drafted. Nevertheless, a group of knowledgeable persons outside the Ministry of Health has been asked to study closely the final draft of the Medicines Bill with a view to advising on the principles and implications of the important provisions. This group of persons includes a senior lecturer in Pharmacy from the University of Singapore, a pharmacist in private practice and a general practitioner.

There are far too many organisations and associations with interest in medicinal products which makes seeking representative views at this stage impracticable. It is, however, proposed to send the Medicines Bill to a Select Committee after its Second Reading in Parliament. This will be the time when interested persons and organisations will be asked to submit their views and memoranda on the Bill.

The Medicines Bill will be presented to Parliament as soon as it is ready. This will be in about three months' time. It should, however, be noted that the Bill, being a complex piece of legislation, may have to be brought into effect in parts. The Medicines Act in the U.K., for example, has still not been completely enforced in all its sections, after it was passed by the British Parliament nearly six years ago. The Minister of State for Communications (Mr Chai Chong Yii): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

In July, 1973, the Minister for Home Affairs appointed a Road Traffic Management and Enforcement Committee to formulate basic policies of Road Traffic Management as well as to co-ordinate the roles of the various departments involved in traffic enforcement and management and to supervise the activities carried out by these departments with a view to achieving greater efficiency and effectiveness in tackling the immediate, short-term and long-term traffic problems. This Committee, chaired by the Permanent Secretary (Home Affairs), comprised representatives from the Ministries of Communications, Finance, Environment, Public

Works Department, Registry of Vehicles, Attorney-General's Chambers, Public Utilities Board and the Police Force. This Committee has been superseded by the Road Transport Action Committee which was established in November, 1973, comprising five Permanent Secretaries from the Ministries of National Development, Communications, Home Affairs and the Budget and Development Divisions of Finance Ministry.

After one year of close study and research, the Road Traffic Management and Enforcement Committee came to the conclusion that our present enforcement system is, amongst other things, noticeably lacking in the following:-

(i) effective means of detecting persistent offenders;

(ii) adequate penalties to deter persistent offenders;

(iii) administrative procedures that allow expedient enforcement action.

To rectify this, the Committee recommended a number of amendments to the Road Traffic Act (Cap. 92). The recommendations of the Committee which have been accepted are incorporated in the Road Traffic (Amendment) Bill.

Clause 2 of the Amendment Bill will empower a Police Officer to require any person driving a motor vehicle on a road to produce his driving licence within 24 hours at such police office or station as may be specified by the officer where the person is unable to produce his licence on the spot.

Clause 4 of the Amendment Bill provides that if a person is convicted of an offence under the Act or is disqualified by a court from holding or obtaining a driving licence, the court shall send a notice of conviction or order of disqualification to the Registrar of Vehicles who will be required to record such particulars of conviction or disqualification and maintain such record for a period not exceeding three years from the date of the conviction or expiry of disqualification as the case may be.

Much publicity has already been given to clause 5 of the Amendment Bill. This concerns the Points Demerit System which aims at identifying and removing dangerous drivers from the roads. It also serves as a psychological deterrence against reckless driving. This system entails the giving of points by administrative means for traffic offences likely to cause accidents. A points penalty table under the Rules will specify the points for various traffic violations.

When a driver has attained a total of 12 or more points within a year, the Registrar of Vehicles will have powers to suspend the driving licence of the driver for a period not exceeding six months. A warning notice, however, will first be sent by the Registrar of Vehicles to the motorist the moment he has accumulated or exceeded six points. On receipt of a notice of suspension, the driver has the right within 14 days to appeal to the Minister against the decision of the Registrar of Vehicles. The Minister's decision on the matter will be final. Any person whose driving licence is suspended will have to surrender it to the Registrar of Vehicles and will be prohibited from driving any motor vehicle on the roads during the period of suspension of his driving licence.

Clause 8 of the Amendment Bill will impose liability upon a motor vehicle owner for parking offences in cases where the particulars of the offending driver are not available. Unless the vehicle owner can furnish particulars of the driver to the police within seven days from the date of issue of the police notice or satisfy the police or the court that the vehicle was, at the relevant time, stolen or had been illegally taken or used, or establish that he did not know and could not, with reasonable diligence, have ascertained the name and address of the driver, the vehicle owner would be liable for the offence.

Clause 9 of the Amendment Bill will enable the Minister to make rules with respect to jaywalking. Over the last three

years, a total of 10,519 pedestrians were killed and injured by motor vehicles. In 1973, a total of 380 persons were killed in road traffic accidents, 185 of whom were pedestrians. While many of these accidents involving pedestrians could be attributed to reckless driving by motorists, a great number of these fatalities were caused by pedestrians crossing the road heedless of traffic conditions. The pedestrians, therefore, need to be disciplined as well.

Under the Amendment Bill, it will be an offence for pedestrians to cross the road other than at places where proper crossing facilities are provided. This would, however, apply to the area 50 metres from either side of any such crossing. Where the crossings are close to one another, the area of enforcement may be extended to cover the length between and a little beyond such crossings. Traffic signs will be erected to indicate the areas of enforcement. As it is not the intention to punish but to educate pedestrians in the proper use of the facilities provided for them, initially small composition fines would be imposed on jaywalkers. This may be increased later if there is no salutary effect. Jaywalking by school children will be referred to principals of their schools for appropriate action to be taken. Aged and disabled persons who are unable to make use of the pedestrian crossing facilities would be exempted.

To empower the courts to impose and enhance penalties in respect of traffic offences, clause 10 of the Amendment Bill provides for the imposition of a fine not exceeding $1,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding three months for the first offence. For a second and subsequent offence, the courts may impose a fine not exceeding $2,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months. For uniformity and consistency, these enhanced penalty provisions would apply to all offences under the various rules and regulations of the Road Traffic Act. The existing penal sections in the rules and regulations will be amended in subsidiary legislation.

A new ticketing system in respect of traffic offences will be introduced under clause 12 of the Amendment Bill. The objective of this is to reduce the present cumbersome paper work which hinders the Traffic Police in its work and saps up extra manpower unnecessarily, thus reducing the effectiveness of enforcement action. Under the proposed ticketing system, a traffic ticket served by the policeman on the motorist, either personally or by registered mail, will be deemed to be both a report as well as a summons to appear in court. If the offence is compoundable, the ticket would also serve as an offer of composition.

To ensure that the Points Demerit System and the ticketing system function effectively and efficiently, the Traffic Police and the Registry of Vehicles have computerised their records and procedures, and the records and procedures of these two departments would be linked. Members of this House may be interested to know that these new enforcement procedures are based on systems successfully applied in countries like the United States, England, Australia and Japan. They have been recommended for adoption here after careful study and research by the Traffic Police, Registry of Vehicles, Attorney-General's Chambers and Computer Services Division of the Ministry of Finance.

Finally, clause 15 of the Amendment Bill will enable the courts to accept certificates endorsed by a police officer not below the rank of inspector, as to the accuracy and reliability of radar speed traps and speedometers of police vehicles. This is required for more effective enforcement against speed hogs whose mania for speed without consideration for others often kill and maim innocent people.

It is now necessary to adopt this amendment, hence this motion.

Sir, I beg to move.

Question put, and agreed to.

Resolved,

That this Parliament resolves that the following amendment, as recommended in paragraph 5 of the First Report of the

Standing Orders Committee and contained in Paper Parl. 4 of 1974, be and is hereby made to the Standing Orders of Parliament: --

Standing Order No. 95:

Paragraph (2) : In line 10, leave out "as Parliament may refer to the Committee" and insert "as the Committee may think fit".ADJOURNMENT: Resolved,

"That Parliament do now adjourn to Wednesday, 6th November, 1974." -[Mr Barker].

Adjourned accordingly at Seven minutes to Six o'clock p.m, to Wednesday, 6th November, 1974.
